name: chicagotribune
text:
Here are today’s top stories in Chicago-area politics, from @byldonovan:

• Mayor Lightfoot pleads for calm
• Despite unrest, Chicago "will reopen tomorrow," mayor says
• Sen. Duckworth blasts Trump as "draft dodging wannabe tin-pot dictator" https://t.co/vcqZtz5hMz

name: chicagotribune
text: Following days of unrest, Mayor Lightfoot calls on Chicago to “stand for peace” and promises to enact a series of long-stalled police reforms. https://t.co/pSqHZXRIIO

name: chicagotribune
text: Officials in Cicero encouraged peaceful protesters but urged others to stay indoors Tuesday night after looters clashed with both police officers and armed vigilantes and two men were shot dead Monday https://t.co/K3UJSrPA4R

name: chicagotribune
text: A new “cocktails to go” law in Illinois allows bars and restaurants with liquor licenses to sell adult beverages for delivery and pickup. But changes to Chicago's municipal code are required before delivery service can begin within city limits. https://t.co/dRFF7HBqFO

name: chicagotribune
text:
Outside a smoldering building on Monday, three friends spent the afternoon sweeping up glass and litter scattered by looters the night before. 

“You’ve got to send a message to everybody that you’re not going to give up,” Malcolm Cherry said. https://t.co/tItH6eCOAu

name: chicagotribune
text: Chicago Mayor Lori Lightfoot promised to enact a series of police reforms and announced a $10 million grant fund to help looted businesses, as she called on Chicagoans to “stand for peace” in the wake of days of unrest across the city and the nation https://t.co/vcj0hqh3lr

name: chicagotribune
text:
“We live in apocalyptic times, but what kind of consciousness do we develop to live through that? ... Right now, I have a heavy heart, a physical pain. Poetry will be a way to metabolize that pain.”

Chicago poet Rosanna Warren on writing in this moment: https://t.co/87qDcutAXs

name: chicagotribune
text: Where do we go from here? Martin Luther King Jr.’s old question endures, writes columnist @cptime. https://t.co/6sFRNzBgTS

name: chicagotribune
text: Mayor Lightfoot is pushing ahead with plans to allow businesses to start gradually reopening Wednesday. But how much of Chicago actually opens back up will vary by neighborhood. https://t.co/6L9hU2ceIk

name: chicagotribune
text: Downtown Chicago will begin to reopen Wednesday, with lowered bridges and resumed Metra and CTA service. https://t.co/AhMQLM8g1L

name: chicagotribune
text: Downtown Chicago will begin to reopen Wednesday, with lowered bridges and resumed Metra and CTA service. https://t.co/QUHZtbxrhF

name: chicagotribune
text: In a speech on Tuesday evening, Mayor Lightfoot promised to enact a series of long-stalled police reforms and announced a $10 million grant fund for looted businesses. https://t.co/ISWKJXU4sL

name: chicagotribune
text:
"We live in apocalyptic times, but what kind of consciousness do we develop to live through that? ... Right now, I have a heavy heart, a physical pain. Poetry will be a way to metabolize that pain."

Chicago poet Rosanna Warren on writing in this moment: https://t.co/nIGUFsEaBF

name: chicagotribune
text: Does the 1968 election offer hope for President Trump? Not likely. If that tumultuous year tells us anything, it's that when things go seriously wrong, the people in charge take the fall, writes columnist @SteveChapman13. https://t.co/JuGE89xe8w

name: chicagotribune
text: After days of road closures and reduced transit service, access to downtown Chicago will start to reopen this morning. https://t.co/qssToRCjpS

name: chicagotribune
text:
“We need to work together to dismantle racism.”

Latino activists speak out about racial tension with black Chicagoans on the city's Southwest Side amid the George Floyd fallout. https://t.co/I0iT6U2Srs

name: chicagotribune
text: Good morning, Chicago. The city starts reopening today despite unrest and COVID-19 concerns. Here’s what you need to know. https://t.co/qEpwAHNTWn

name: chicagotribune
text: Liberal Democratic governors and mayors have been mugged by reality, writes columnist @John_Kass https://t.co/dL6l2MtEiw

name: chicagotribune
text: “I don’t want anyone else to feel this pain,” said Mayra Velazquez, who lost her husband and parents to COVID-19. “People are so anxious to go out and lead a normal life. ... The only thing I would like is to be in my house with my parents and my husband.” https://t.co/PLJ8rVjhqA

name: chicagotribune
text: Former Woodstock firefighter and paramedic Ryan Mains went on a 21½-hour odyssey on Saturday as a tribute to the 130 firefighters and EMS personnel who took their own lives in 2019. https://t.co/2awNa19qL4

name: chicagotribune
text: At least 20 people were shot from Tuesday afternoon into Wednesday morning, according to police, a number that’s still high after a notably violent weekend. https://t.co/Z4C0xUOy5r

name: chicagotribune
text: Fiona Whelan Prine, wife of singer-songwriter John Prine, who died from complications of COVID-19, urged Tennessee lawmakers to expand absentee voting so people won't have to risk their health to vote. https://t.co/po7qEutuX5

name: chicagotribune
text: The Milwaukee Brewers say a man illegally entered Miller Park and caused minor damage to the playing field Tuesday morning. https://t.co/KIEdJjKmh2

name: chicagotribune
text: “The system is corrupt and they want to see minorities fight against one another to weaken us. We need to work together to dismantle racism.” https://t.co/OqdAkRklW1

name: chicagotribune
text: The calmer night came as many cities intensified their curfews, with authorities in New York and Washington ordering people off streets while it was still daylight. https://t.co/NktztcO8NL

name: chicagotribune
text: Regarding the protests going on in respond to the death of George Floyd, Key says he is feeling many emotions, including exhaustion from the systemic racism. https://t.co/496LJl4sbM

name: chicagotribune
text: Former Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein is defending his decision to appoint a special counsel to scrutinize ties between Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign and Russia. https://t.co/U0y1ZTJqBb

name: chicagotribune
text: Defense Secretary Mark Esper said Wednesday he opposes use of Insurrection Act, which would allow President Donald Trump to use active-duty forces for law enforcement duties. https://t.co/65lr6hSi4G

name: chicagotribune
text: A review documents how the COVID-19 pandemic shook longstanding confidence in the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and its leader. From The New York Times. https://t.co/EGWJiml4iP

name: chicagotribune
text: George Floyd’s family is calling for the arrest of all 4 police officers involved in his death https://t.co/hhO7gESxjn

name: chicagotribune
text: Here’s what’s happening today with COVID-19 in the Chicago area https://t.co/VqKUpwWsHt

name: chicagotribune
text: Chicago is proceeding with plans to reopen Wednesday, even as tensions remain high over the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis and the looming threat of the coronavirus outbreak https://t.co/xaOAdAKgun

name: chicagotribune
text: After days of protests following George Floyd’s killing by Minneapolis police, people are looking for ways to directly support Black-owned restaurants in Chicago. Luckily, there are some resources available for people to do just that. https://t.co/8QFucd66QJ

name: chicagotribune
text: A Chicago man faces felony charges after police say he broke dozens of windows in a school around the corner from his home on the Northwest Side early Wednesday. https://t.co/5KSDyhXlSR
